H0.text: Natural selection is the process responsible for genetic differences in allele frequencies when a small group of organisms colonizes a new habitat, causing the population to be genetically distinct from the parent population.

H1.text: Disruptive selection is the process that causes a small group of organisms colonizing a new habitat to become genetically different from the parent population due to differences in allele frequencies.

H2.text: Genetic drift is the process that causes a small group of organisms colonizing a new habitat to become genetically different from the parent population due to differences in allele frequencies.

H3.text: Genetic equilibrium is the process responsible when a small group of organisms colonizes a new habitat and the resulting population may be genetically different from the parent population due to differences in allele frequencies.

A4.text: The difference in gene frequencies between the original population and colony may also trigger the two groups to diverge significantly over the course of many generations. As the difference, or genetic distance, increases, the two separated populations may become distinct, both genetically and phenetically, although not only genetic drift but also natural selection, gene flow, and mutation contribute to this divergence.
